metadata.case_name: Ramanlal Bhogilal Shah v. Union of India

facts.text: Petitioner was General Manager of United Commercial Bank Ltd. till January 17, 1968 when he became Chairman and whole time Director. Upon nationalisation, appointed Custodian till September 1, 1971.
United Commercial Bank booked forward exchange contract for Hindustan Motors for Â£9,32,617 at rate of 1s. 529/32d per rupee on June 4, 1966. Rupee devalued on June 6, 1966.
Summons under S.19F of Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947 served on petitioner on May 24, 1971. Examined on June 3, 16, 17, 1971 regarding the forward exchange contract.

Petitioner arrested under S.19B of Exchange Act on August 31, 1971 at 10.35 a.m. Grounds of arrest served, alleging contravention of S.42 and S.22 punishable under S.23, with petitioner in charge and responsible, failed to prove lack of knowledge or due diligence under S.23C.
Produced before Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta on August 31, 1971; released on bail of Rs.10,000 with directions to contact Investigating Officer every alternate day.

Magistrate orders: September 6, 1971 - time till Dec 6, 1971; December 6, 1971 - time till March 6, 1972; March 6, 1972 - time till June 1972, referencing Supreme Court proceedings re Hindustan Motors writ.

FIR dated November 9, 1971 under S.154 CrPC by CBI, offences S.120B r/w S.420 IPC and S.2 r/w S.23(1)(b) Exchange Act, accused: management and officers of United Commercial Bank and Hindustan Motors re same June 4, 1966 contract. Order Nov 25, 1971 under S.155(2) CrPC.

Summons under S.19F issued April 17, 1972 to appear April 28, 1972 re transaction of exchange contract from Hindustan Motors June 4, 1966. Petitioner objected citing Art.20(3). Deputy Director refused withdrawal on April 22, 1972.

legal_issues.text: Whether the petitioner is a person accused of an offence within Art.20(3) of the Constitution after arrest under S.19B with grounds served and/or lodging of FIR, so as to be protected from summons under S.19F of Exchange Act to give evidence.

petitioner_arguments.text: After examination under S.19F and arrest with grounds accusing petitioner of offence under Exchange Act, petitioner is accused within Art.20(3). At latest, FIR under S.154 CrPC makes him accused.
Position under Exchange Act different from Customs Act; enquiry under S.23(1)(a) is for offence without further complaint.

respondent_arguments.text: Arrest under S.19B and grounds served do not make person accused until complaint filed under S.23; relies on Romesh Chandra Mehta v. State of West Bengal.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Romesh Chandra Mehta v. State of West Bengal, (1969) 2 SCR 461

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioner not specifically named in FIR.

court_reasoning.text: Facts differ from Romesh Mehta as enquiry under S.19F made and conclusions reached; but unnecessary to decide first point as second prevails: FIR lodges formal accusation making petitioner accused.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioner included in 'management and other officers' of bank in FIR re same contract; in charge and responsible per arrest grounds.

court_reasoning.text: Art.20(3) protects only from compelled self-incriminating testimony; must answer questions not tending to incriminate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Testimony incriminating if by itself tends to make case probable against accused.

holdings.text: Lodging of FIR makes person accused within Art.20(3); protection extends to compelled testimony obtained previously.
Petitioner cannot be compelled to be witness against himself but must answer non-incriminating questions; summons not set aside.

precedents_cited.case_name: Romesh Chandra Mehta v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Arrest and grounds do not formally accuse until complaint filed; but facts differ here due to prior enquiry.
FIR is formal accusation; Art.20(3) protects from compelled testimony post-accusation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raja Narayanlal Bansilal v. Maneck Phiroz Mistry
precedents_cited.relevance: Formal accusation required for Art.20(3); FIR qualifies.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. Kathi Kalu Oghad
precedents_cited.relevance: Self-incriminating testimony must tend to make case probable.

statutes_cited.name: Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers of summons, arrest, enquiry, offences, penalties; protection under Art.20(3) applies post-accusation.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: FIR lodges accusation making person accused.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: No compulsion to be witness against oneself; writ for fundamental rights.

outcome.summary: Petition allowed to extent declaring petitioner accused within Art.20(3), but summons under S.19F not set aside; must appear and answer non-incriminating questions.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that petitioner is accused; no quashing of summons.

key_quotes.text: "It is well settled that with the lodging of a first information report a person is accused of an offence within the meaning of art. 20(3)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on when person becomes accused.

key_quotes.text: "Normally a person stands in the character of an accused when a First Information Report is lodged against him..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Cites Shah J. in Romesh Mehta defining accused.

key_quotes.text: "In order that a testimony... may be said to have been self-incriminatory... it must be of such a character that by itself it should have the tendency of incriminating the accused..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
